comments.commentBody: I don't agree. Democrats will agree to any and all demands of Republicans just to keep the government running. As far as I am concerned. let the Republicans shut  down the government again and suffer the consequences. That is why we have all of the Republicans austerity  demands met and non of the Democrats. The Democrats are not ready for prime time, and we need  primaries and  and replacement for the senators who want to work with  Republicans to punish the poor.
Please God, let them be chastened, severely!

comments.userLocation: Bronxville, NY, writing from Nosara, Costa Rica
comments.commentBody: This is not a "compromise" that I find pleasing.  How about a compromise on returning to a progressive tax system that requires the wealthy to pay the costs of their becoming richer and richer?  How about a compromise that lifts the working poor out of poverty by raising the minimum wage? How is that the only compromises we seem to get take us further down the path of inequality?  Not pleasing. Not at all pleasing.

While I am appalled at cuts in the food stamp program, I am pleased that the ultimate House-Senate compromise legislation staves off the worst of the rollbacks supported by House Republicans. The legislative system still can drive compromise.

I hope that those adversely affected by the food stamp cuts and those who disapprove of taking sustenance out of the mouths of poor children and families will vote Democratic in the 2014 elections. The Republican Party will shift course only after it is chastened at the ballot box.
Bravo, David.  What is your secret?

comments.userLocation: The flats of e'side Buffalo, NY
comments.commentBody:
Go for A century, David,
I'm right behind you... on my Fuji.

"Radical life extension smacks of an intemperate claim to have unlocked the fundamental mystery of life. That is dangerous territory. "

Speak for yourself, I have already exceeded the the American life expectancy, still do 60 and 70 mile bike rides in the hills, do carpentry work around the house, just finished some plumbing work, so I will just keep on for a few more years. And I can afford to hire a handyman to help when needed.

And so it is to imagine that Democratic politicians are actual human beings --after all, with some crumbs thrown in, Dems follow along.

Even the President hailed the past budget deal throwing the unemployed down the drain as "a hopeful sing... we can actually work together to get things done".

With friends as the Dems, who needs enemies?

Why is it hard to imagine that good, middle class people resist being taxed for the benefit of the unworthy poor and rent-seeking rich? I for one am a Republican and a real human being; I am just tired of paying outrageous and unfair taxes for the benefit of moochers.
It's only so when the definition includes people without hearts. Perhaps we should find a better term. I dislike the association.
It is hard to imagine that Republicans are actual human beings.

The Senate and House have passed their respective farm bills and now have met to work out a compromise version. Stabenow has done a reasonable job in the circumstances. The House bill cut food stamp support by $40 billion, the Senate bill-- which needed to garner sufficient support to avoid a Republican filibuster-- cut $4 billion. The House-Senate compromise calls for an $8 billion cut. Say what you will, but that's reasonable as a compromise figure.

To do better, it's necessary to return the House to Democratic control in the 2014 midterms, while holding the Senate in Democratic hands.
Did you actually read the comments? You've got the percentages totally backwards.

Stories like this one, about fraud on Wall St, underlines the need to tax stock trading. It also underlines the need to stop taxing capital gains at lower rates than earned income.

When a middle class person sells the family home, there are large transfer taxes. When a rich person sells an equivalent amount of stock, there is no tax at all. Few large stock transactions are done by middle class people, so this amounts to subsidizing the rich.

A much larger percent of rich people's income is the result of capital gains than it is of middle class people. Almost all of these gains are trades in existing stock which do not involve innovation or job creation. But the rich person's capital gains taxes are about half the middle class person's tax on equivalent earned income.

These things are unwise and immoral subsidies to the already rich. Transaction taxes on stock sales, and higher taxes on capital gains, are needed. Similarly, inheritance taxes are now virtually non-existent, another blow to the middle class and subsidy to the rich.

Tax unearned income! Tax stock transactions! Tax inheritance! For more suggestions, go to YouTube and find Comedy Party Platform. And yes, vote for me in 2016.

www.youtube.com/tra1776
George Raft.  Merry Christmas.  Good night.

I continue to e saddened and surprised that the American people continue to accept the shredding of the social safety net.  Those who vote Republican-- especially those with limited means-- are reaping the whirlwind.
what are you insane.. drugs and alcohol/addiction definitely hold prejudice, especially when your father is the mayor of new york.
"...listen to your heart..." As opposed to her father's handlers? Get real.
That's what all politicians and celebrities say they will do when caught.
Good point.  This may be the beginning of a conversation about substance abuse among college age kids that we haven't been having.

Myself and the deBlasio family couldn't be more diametrically politically opposed but I am cheering for his daughters continuing success combating her addictions. I also applaud and thank her for sharing her story and using her new celebrity to maybe help the many people just like herself with their own problems. Thank you Chiara!

You nailed it. Why aren't you on the beat? Great piece, astute and perceptive.
Seems like his team wrote every other comment - cue the "soft piano music".

ACW,

Excellent commentary on Huey Long, a true populist who actually accomplished much for the poor and downtrodden in Louisiana. Christie is just bully, romanticized by the same ilk that love to watch bullies humiliate people on the fake reality TV trash hour that passes as entertainment. And then the legion of apologists who use the crazy logic that boils down to "well, one of my neighbors is a criminal so it's alright for my other neighbor to be a criminal".
Actually, I, for one, have not coordinated with anybody. I'm surprised you don't recognize a big tantrummy baby bully when you see one.
Yeah, right.  Nice try at accusing the left at what the right is actually guilty of doing.

Bullying doesn't equate to personality. Liberals don't fear Christie, they scorn him and with good reason.

Christie has accomplished nothing as governor except getting reelected. His success doesn't benefit anyone else in the state.

The anti-Chrisie static is a carefully coordinated attack by the left, they are scared to death of a republican with a personality, especially a successful governor like Christie.
The white noise coming from liberals always gives away their feelings.
Attack attack attack = fear.
Governor Christie is a jerk and not fit for higher official. As a Democrat I was considering voting for him if he ran for President. Now I would not and consider him unfit for the position.
Like canceling the tunnel at a cost of billions and an opportunity cost of tens of billions to... curry favor with Republican primary voters?

Good point.
But it's 'lying', not 'laying'. Bodies, by definition, can't do anything as active as to 'lay'.
I've read many stories over the years about Christie's bullying tactics.  This is not a new story.  Where have you been?

{Why has it taken so long for the media to make this an issue? I find it hard to believe he has done this for so long without there having been "bodies" laying around.}

Who do you think elevated him to this status other than the Democrats. Who would you rather run against in 2016? A man of his caliber with how many skeletons in his closet or Jeb Bush with all his power, money and influence? Who could and may possibly destroy Hillary.

As long as Christie's center stage think of all the attention and campaign donations he's pulling away from others and why it's the Republicans who're behind this and now want him gone.

With him being head of the Republican Governors Association they can ill afford to have him running around the Country becoming even more of a detriment to the party. He is completely out of control and they know it.
Why has it taken so long for the media to make this an issue? I find it hard to believe he has done this for so long without there having been "bodies" laying around.

More disconcerting than the possibility that Christie was behind the closures that gridlocked Fort Lee is his astonishingly cavalier dismissal of the whole thing. Instead of being genuinely concerned that thousands of New Jerseyans were put at risk for as yet unknown reasons and demanding an investigation of his own, he mocks the whole thing as 'not that big of a deal'. What kind of leadership is this? And Landshark, if your family resided in Fort Lee and your spouse had a heart attack during those four days, and the ambulance you called couldn't get to your house in time, how would you be reacting to the governor's dismissal of the lane closures as 'not a big deal'?

Got leadership?

The real tell about how intimidated people are:  Neither of our two (2) Democratic US Senators will comment on the "bridge" affair. It took Rockefeller, from W. VA to bring it up in Washington as an interstate commerce issue.
Would you say this if he was not on your side?
Agony is allowed to exist in more than one context.

About 20 years ago, I traveled to the Lake Placid area on business. With time to kill before our flight back, we decided to tour some of the Olympic facilities. The "Miracle on Ice" arena holds about 10% of the fans that I thought were there while I watched on television.

We then traveled to the ski jumping venue, rode a chairlift to the base of the tower, took an elevator up as high as it went, climbed about four flights of stairs, and, after spitting off the top, made our way out to the bench where the jumpers sit just before their long slide down the ramp.

I took a seat, looked down that long hill, and thought, "Bigger than mine."

I hate to admit it, but I'm afraid the same is true with respect to the young women who are -- FINALLY -- going to jump next year. I look forward to the event, but only as an impressed observer.

Nice job, Mr. Jerome. Keep scattering those cockroaches.

Christie's an obvious narcissist and rather than embrace criticism and ask why, this aberration called ego, gets in the way. It's not difficult to see why he appeals to some, but it's also not prudent to allow this man more suited to a state where if the same things were done that are legal in New Jersey, would be illegal in many other states. Thuggery in assassins is encouraged, it's also encouraged in the Mafia, but when it comes to the highest office, it's not only not acceptable but dangerous.  It's strange that he appeals to people, but if people are raised by abusive parents or guardians, and he surely appears to embrace those attributes, such men or women cannot be considered for higher office. . Christie doesn't need to change, since he won't, he simply needs to forget the presidency, it won't happen, but if it did, it would mean we've got a thug in high office, look out, world, this guy isn't qualified to be our president, he would make a good sword bearing warrior, however.

I think you are mistaking criticism of the father for criticism of the daughter. I don't see much at all of the latter. The former is entirely justified. This is just the second chapter in the political exploitation of a vulnerable and young woman.
DeBlasio is just another pol.
While the Feds continue to monitor the SEA (Syrian Electronic Army) why hasn't Obama said anything about it?    Is it because his policies are too pro-Assad?
